p: Figure 2 and eqn 4 suggest that containment would be cheaper than eradication only when the size of the occupied zone exceeds a multiple of the dispersal distance determined by seed bank longevity and the discount rate. This threshold is similar to Cacho et al.'s ‘critical decision points’ (Cacho et al. 2008). Biologically, this means that containment is less likely to be viable for species exhibiting large effective dispersal distances via fat-tailed distributions, as found by Panetta & Cacho ( 2014). The longer an infestation has been established and the further it has spread, the more likely it is that a containment strategy will be a cheaper option than eradication. This is a similar result to that reached by Sharov & Liebhold ( 1998a) for gypsy moth in the United States. Of course, the possibility that neither eradication nor containment is economically viable should also be explicitly considered (Cacho et al. 2008). Some studies have suggested that when funds are limited, optimal outcomes may involve partial containment coupled with fecundity reduction actions in the occupied zone (Panetta & Cacho 2012).
